data.title: time Allstar recipient, is born – The Irish News
data.meta_description: Kick off your day with a few sporting greats, dates and a quick quiz blitz..
data.text:
ON THIS DAY

1907: The Football Players' and Trainers' Union was formed. In 1958, the name was changed to the Professional Footballers' Association.

1950: Defending world bantamweight champion Vic Toweel put challenger Danny O'Sullivan on the canvas a record 14 times during their title fight in Johannesburg en route to an 11th-round victory.

1997: Five players were sent off in the league game between Wigan and Bristol Rovers, with Rovers playing the last 20 minutes of the match with only seven men.

1999: Neil Warnock was appointed manager of Sheffield United - the Blades' fifth manager in less than three years. He would guide them to the Premier League during an eight-year spell in charge.

2004: Walter Smith was appointed manager of the Scotland national team. The former Rangers and Everton boss succeeded Berti Vogts, who had quit his position on November 1 after picking up only two points from the opening three World Cup qualifiers.

2010: Russia was awarded the hosting rights for the 2018 World Cup finals, beating rivals England and joint bids between Spain/Portugal and Holland/Belgium, while Qatar won the right to host the 2022 World Cup.

BIRTHDAYS

Pat Spillane (GAA) – Former Kerry footballer, winner of eight All-Ireland medals and nine time Allstar recipient, born 1955.

Brian McEniff (GAA) – Former Donegal player and All-Ireland winning manager, winner of two Ulster SFC medals as a player, and an All-Star recipient in 1972, born 1942.

Jay Haas (golf) - Veteran US Tour winner, born 1953.

Nigel Spackman (soccer) - Former Chelsea, Liverpool and Rangers midfielder, born 1960.

David Batty (soccer) - Former Leeds and England midfielder, born 1968.

Nick Beal (rugby union) - Former Northampton, England and Lions full-back, born 1970.

Francesco Toldo (soccer) - Former Fiorentina, Inter Milan and Italy goalkeeper, born 1971.

Monica Seles (tennis) - Serbia-born American, a winner of nine Grand Slam titles, who became youngest ever world number one aged 17, born 1973.

Graham Kavanagh (soccer) - Former Sunderland and Republic of Ireland midfielder, born 1973.

Jan Ullrich (cycling) - Became the first German to win the Tour de France in 1997, although in 2013 he admitted to blood doping in his career, born 1973.

Chris Burke (soccer) - Former Rangers and Scotland midfielder, now with Ross County, born 1983.

Aaron Rodgers (American football) - Super Bowl-winning quarterback and MVP with the Green Bay Packers in 2010, born 1983.

Gaston Ramirez (soccer) - Middlesbrough and Uruguay midfielder, born 1990.

QUICK QUIZ BLITZ

1. In what years did Cork last achieve a three-in-row of Munster SFC titles?

2. How many Premier League titles has Arsene Wenger won as Arsenal boss?

3. In what year did France last win the RBS 6 Nations title?

4. Tigers Woods has won 14 major titles, but which was his last and in what year?

5. Who finished top scorer in the 2001 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship?

(See quiz answers at bottom)

SPORT ON TV

Friday, December 2

GAA: Off the Ball, an off beat look at recent football developments, eir Sport 1900.

SOCCER: FA Cup, Macclesfield v Oxford - BBC Two England, BBC Two Northern Ireland, BBC Two Scotland 1930 and eir Sport 1 1945; Championship, Nottingham Forest v Newcastle - Sky Sports 1 1900; Scottish Championship - BT Sport 2 1930; Bundesliga, Mainz v Bayern Munich - BT Sport/ESPN 1930; A-League, Melbourne Victory v Perth Glory - BT Sport 1 0845.

RUGBY UNION: Aviva Premiership, Sale v Exeter - BT Sport 1 1900; Guinness PRO12, Ospreys v Edinburgh - BBC Two Wales 1930; HSBC Sevens World Series, Dubai Sevens - Sky Sports 2 0600.

SNOOKER: UK Championship - BBC Two England, Eurosport 1 and Eurosport 2 1300, Eurosport 1 1845 and Eurosport 2 1900.

GOLF: European Tour, Alfred Dunhill Championship - Sky Sports 4 0830 and 1230; PGA Tour, Hero World Challenge - Sky Sports 4 1830.

BASKETBALL: NBA, Chicago Bulls v Cleveland Cavaliers - BT Sport 1 0100 (Sat).

CRICKET: Ram Slam T20 Challenge, Knights v Highveld Lions - Sky Sports 3 1600.

Saturday, December 3

SOCCER: Premier League, Manchester City v Chelsea - Sky Sports 1 1130, West Ham v Arsenal - BT Sport 1 1700; FA Cup, Charlton v MK Dons - eir Sport 1 1455; Championship, Leeds v Aston Villa - Sky Sports 1 1715; Scottish Premiership, Motherwell v Celtic - Sky Sports 5 1200; LaLiga, Granada v Sevilla and Atletico Madrid v Espanyol - Sky Sports 3 1155 and 1925; Serie A, Napoli v

Inter Milan - eir Sport 1 1655; 2.Bundesliga, 1860 Munich v Dynamo Dresden - BT Sport 1 1200; Portuguese Liga, Porto v Braga - BT Sport 2 2030; A-League, Central Coast Mariners v Western Sydney Wanderers followed by Melbourne City v Brisbane Roar - BT Sport 1 0630.

RUGBY UNION: Autumn Test, England v Australia - Sky Sports 2 1330; Aviva Premiership, Leicester v Northampton - BT Sport 2 1630; Guinness PRO12, Cardiff v Ulster - Sky Sports 2 1700, Leinster v Newport Gwent Dragons - S4C 1915; Top 14, La Rochelle v Racing 92 - Sky Sports 2 1930; HSBC Sevens World Series, Dubai Sevens - Sky Sports 2 0600.

SNOOKER: UK Championship - Eurosport 2 1245 and 1845, BBC One 1315, BBC Two England 1630 and 1900.

GOLF: European Tour, Alfred Dunhill Championship - Sky Sports 4 1000; PGA Tour, Hero World Challenge - Sky Sports 4 1700.

CYCLING: Revolution Series - Eurosport 1 1915.

MIXED MARTIAL ARTS: UFC - BT Sport 2 0100 (Sun).

QUICK QUIZ BLITZ answers: 1 1993-1995; 2 Three; 3 2010; 4 US Open in 2008; 5 Pádraic Joyce (3-45).
